column2: Producers of portable batteries or, where appointed in accordance with Article 57(1), producer responsibility organisations, shall ensure that all waste portable batteries, Light Means of Transport (LMT) batteries, and SLI batteries, regardless of their nature, chemical composition, condition, brand, or origin, are collected separately
column5: The implementation of TA3.15 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.23, as the collection of waste batteries will support the development of a closed-loop system for battery production and recycling, which can contribute to the production of renewable hydrogen.

column2: Producers of portable batteries or producer responsibility organisations shall attain, and maintain durably, at least the following collection targets for waste portable batteries: 45% by 31 December 2023, 63% by 31 December 2027, 73% by 31 December 2030
column5: The implementation of TA3.16 will also have a positive impact on TA4.23, as the increased collection of waste batteries will support the development of a closed-loop system for battery production and recycling.

column2: Producers of LMT (Light Means of Transport) batteries or producer responsibility organisations shall attain, and maintain durably, at least the following collection targets of waste LMT batteries: 51% by 31 December 2028, 61% by 31 December 2031
column5: The implementation of TA3.17 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.23, as the collection of waste LMT batteries will support the development of a closed-loop system for battery production and recycling.

column2: Recycled content in industrial batteries, electric vehicle batteries, LMT batteries, and SLI batteries: Cobalt: 16% by 2031 (26% by 2036), Lead: 85% (85%), Nickel: 6% (12%), Lithium: 6% (15%)
column5: The implementation of TA3.18 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.20, as the increased use of recycled materials in battery production will reduce the demand for primary materials and support the development of renewable energy technologies.

column2: All batteries incorporated in market products shall be readily removable and replaceable by the end-user at any time during the lifetime
column5: The implementation of TA3.19 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.23, as the design for recyclability and removability will support the development of a closed-loop system for battery production and recycling.

column2: Reduce landfill to a maximum of 10% of municipal waste
column5: The implementation of TA3.2 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.30, as reducing landfill waste will support the development of a circular economy and reduce the environmental impacts of waste management.

column2: Recycling shall achieve at least the following targets for recycling efficiency: No later than 31 December 2025, 75% by average weight of lead-acid batteries, 80% by average weight of nickel-cadmium batteries, 50% by average weight of other waste batteries
column5: The implementation of TA3.20 will also have a positive impact on TA4.23, as the increased recycling of waste batteries will support the development of a closed-loop system for battery production and recycling.

column2: Recycling shall achieve at least the following targets for recycling efficiency: No later than 31 December 2025, 65% by average weight of lithium-based batteries
column5: The implementation of TA3.21 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.23, as the increased recycling of lithium-based batteries will support the development of a closed-loop system for battery production and recycling.

column2: All recycling shall achieve at least the following targets for recovery of materials: No later than 31 December 2027, 90% for cobalt, copper, lead, nickel
column5: The implementation of TA3.22 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.20, as the increased recovery of critical materials will support the development of renewable energy technologies.

column2: All recycling shall achieve at least the following targets for recovery of materials: No later than 31 December 2027, 50% lithium
column5: The implementation of TA3.23 will also have a positive impact on TA4.20, as the increased recovery of lithium will support the development of renewable energy technologies.

column2: Reduce the generation of food waste in processing and manufacturing by 10% in comparison to the amount generated in 2020
column5: The implementation of TA3.24 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.36, as reducing food waste will support the development of a circular economy and reduce the environmental impacts of food production.

column2: In the first phase, from 2020 up to 2024, the strategic objective is to install at least 6 GW of renewable hydrogen electrolysers in the EU and the production of up to 1 million tonnes of renewable hydrogen.
column5: The implementation of TA4.20 may have a negative impact on TA3.11, as the increased production of renewable hydrogen may lead to increased energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions in the short term.

column2: In a third phase, from 2030 onwards and towards 2050, renewable hydrogen technologies should reach maturity and be deployed at large scale to reach all hard-to-decarbonise sectors where other alternatives might not be feasible or have higher costs.
column5: The implementation of TA4.21 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.12, as the large-scale deployment of renewable hydrogen technologies will support the development of a low-carbon economy and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Build three million public electric charging points by 2030. Build one million public electric charging points by 2025.
column5: The implementation of TA4.22 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.15, as the increased deployment of public electric charging points will support the development of a circular economy and reduce the environmental impacts of battery production and recycling.

column2: Build 1.000 hydrogen stations by 2030. By 2025, build half of the 1.000 hydrogen stations needed for 2030.
column5: The implementation of TA4.23 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.18, as the increased deployment of hydrogen stations will support the development of a low-carbon economy and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Member States shall ensure that, at the end of each year, starting from the year referred to in Article 26, the following power output targets are met cumulatively: (a) for each light-duty battery electric vehicle registered in their territory, a total power output of at least 1,3 kW is provided through publicly accessible recharging stations
column5: The implementation of TA4.25 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.15, as the increased deployment of public recharging stations will support the development of a circular economy and reduce the environmental impacts of battery production and recycling.

column2: Member States shall ensure that along the TEN-T core and comprehensive networks, publicly accessible recharging pools dedicated to light-duty vehicles are deployed in each direction of travel with a maximum distance of 60 km in-between them offering a power output of at least 600kW and including at least one recharging point with an individual power output of at least 150 kW.
column5: The implementation of TA4.26 will also have a positive impact on TA3.15, as the increased deployment of public recharging pools will support the development of a circular economy and reduce the environmental impacts of battery production and recycling.

column2: By 31 December 2030 (with intermediate 2025 and 2027 targets), along the TEN-T core road network, publicly accessible recharging pools dedicated to heavy-duty electric vehicles are deployed in each direction of travel with a maximum distance of 60 km between them
column5: The implementation of TA4.27 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.17, as the increased deployment of public recharging pools will support the development of a circular economy and reduce the environmental impacts of battery production and recycling.

column2: by 31 December 2030, in each safe and secure parking area at least four publicly accessible recharging stations dedicated to heavy-duty electric vehicles with an individual power output of at least 100 kW are deployed
column5: The implementation of TA4.28 will also have a positive impact on TA3.17, as the increased deployment of public recharging stations will support the development of a circular economy and reduce the environmental impacts of battery production and recycling.

column2: By 31 December 2030, in each urban node publicly accessible recharging points dedicated to heavy-duty electric vehicles with an aggregated power output of at least 1 800 kW are deployed, provided by recharging stations with an individual power output of at least 150 kW.
column5: The implementation of TA4.29 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.17, as the increased deployment of public recharging points will support the development of a circular economy and reduce the environmental impacts of battery production and recycling.

column2: Member States shall ensure that, by 31 December 2030, at least one publicly accessible hydrogen refuelling station is deployed in each urban node.
column5: The implementation of TA4.30 will also have a positive impact on TA3.18, as the increased deployment of hydrogen refuelling stations will support the development of a low-carbon economy and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Member States shall ensure that, by 31 December 2030, publicly accessible hydrogen refuelling stations designed for a minimum cumulative capacity of 1 tonne per day and equipped with at least a 700 bar dispenser are deployed with a maximum distance of 200 km between them along the TEN-T core network
column5: The implementation of TA4.31 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.18, as the increased deployment of hydrogen refuelling stations will support the development of a low-carbon economy and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Member States shall ensure that at all airports of the TEN-T core network and TEN-T comprehensive network, the provision of electricity supply to stationary aircraft is ensured by 31 December 2029, at all aircraft remote stands used for commercial air transport operations to embark or disembark passengers or to load or unload goods
column5: The implementation of TA4.32 will also have a positive impact on TA3.20, as the increased use of electricity supply to stationary aircraft will support the development of a circular economy and reduce the environmental impacts of waste management.

column2: Member States shall ensure that at least one installation providing shore-side electricity supply to inland waterway vessels is deployed at all TEN-T core inland waterway ports by 1 January 2025, at least one installation providing shore-side electricity supply to inland waterway vessels is deployed at all TEN-T comprehensive inland waterway ports by 1 January 2030.
column5: The implementation of TA4.33 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.20, as the increased use of shore-side electricity supply to inland waterway vessels will support the development of a circular economy and reduce the environmental impacts of waste management.

column2: Member States shall ensure that a minimum shore-side electricity supply for seagoing container ships and seagoing passenger ships is provided in TEN-T maritime ports.
column5: The implementation of TA4.34 will also have a positive impact on TA3.20, as the increased use of shore-side electricity supply to seagoing container ships and passenger ships will support the development of a circular economy and reduce the environmental impacts of waste management.
